title-group.article-title: Nonparametric Estimation of the Effects of Advertising: The Case of Lydia Pinkham*

contrib-group.aff: Universidad del País Vasco, Bilbao, Spain

abstract.p: This article reexamines some of the issues raised subsequent to the classical research by Palda (1964). We use a nonparametric estimation method that allows us to incorporate both seasonal and smoothness constraints to estimate the parameters of a demand function using monthly data on Lydia Pinkham's vegetable compound. The analysis indicates that the parameters of the estimated demand equation are not constant throughout the long period of the data, which covers the whole life cycle of the product.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The famous data set of the Lydia Pinkham Medicine Company, which is included in many econometric textbooks as well as in some software packages, has inspired a great many econometric analyses. This old data set (1907–60) has been used in a lot of different approaches to such an extent that we can follow the evolution of (a part of) econometric methodology just by reviewing “Lydiametric” literature (Pollay1979).

Most previous attempts to estimate the relationship between advertising and sales using the data on Lydia Pinkham's vegetable compound focused on estimating the current and lagged effects of advertising, the correct form of the relationship or the direction of causality between the two variables. Few attempts have been made to allow the response parameters in the firm demand function to vary over time. Many factors can alter the relationships among those variables, so it is reasonable to suppose that the parameters relating sales and advertising may vary over time.

The original dissertation by Palda (1964),The Measurement of Cumulative Advertising,focused on the Koyck (1954) distributed lag model. Palda estimated a large number of regressions and, selecting the best fitting models, concluded that “the distributed lag models both give a better fit to the Pinkham data and forecast better than the models which do not incorporate lagged effects.” After that, a lot of authors questioned the Koyck scheme in this context, proposed more general models, and used more refined estimation procedures. In this vast literature, we can find, among others, the current‐effects model (Clarke and McCann1973), the brand‐loyalty model (based on early work by Kuehn1961), the Pascal lag distribution model (Kmenta1971), transfer function models (Heyse and Wei1985), and the error correction model (Baghestani1991; Lee, Shin, and Chung1996). The estimation procedures go from frequency domain regression (Clarke and McCann1973), maximum likelihood estimator (Weiss, Houston, and Windal1978), and Box‐Jenkins transfer function (Helmer and Johansson1977) to cointegration analysis (Baghestani1991; Lee et al.1996).

The Pinkham data seem to be ideal for studying the sales‐advertising relationship. The Pinkham product (a herbal extract in an alcoholic solution) had no direct competitor, and advertising was basically the only form of marketing employed. Given this monopoly position, the models proposed for analyzing the sales‐advertising relationship need not concern themselves with any competitor's advertising, which simplifies them substantially. Moreover, Pinkham was one of the first large nationwide advertisers in the United States.

Some authors try to incorporate variability into coefficients by using dummy variables. This decision, however, is based on two assumptions. First, specifying dummy variables requires information about the moments at which changes occur. The second, and more important, assumption is that, under the assumption of uncorrelated errors, all changes are deterministic in the sense that, once the economic context changes, the impact on the coefficients is immediate and remains constant until the next economic change. In this context, a time‐varying coefficient model appears naturally. Chow (1984), Harvey (1989), and Nicholls and Pagan (1985) present detailed reviews of the main approaches taken in the relevant literature. The flexibility that comes from modeling time‐varying coefficients permits the incorporation of constant jumps (as in the dummy specification), gradual reactions to economic changes, or a combination of both. Obviously, if one knows when changes occur and how long their impact will last and can guarantee that the changes remain constant, then the dummy variable specification works well. Otherwise, we have a classical misspecification problem. To avoid these problems, a time‐varying coefficient regression model is more appropriate for analyzing possible changes in coefficients. Many works show the need for this kind of model; for example, Deaton and Muellbauer (1980). Diewert and Wales (1987), and Song, Liu, and Romilly (1996), among others, propose time‐varying coefficient models for consumption; Doran and Rambaldi (1997) and Song, Liu, and Romilly (1997) introduce time‐varying coefficients into the almost ideal demand system; and Narasimham, Swamy, and Reed (1988) and Doran (1992) do likewise for production functions. These authors estimate their models through Kalman filtering techniques (Kalman1960), where coefficients are assumed to be stochastic following a prespecific distribution. The disadvantages of this approach are mainly the following: the need to determine a priori all the distributions involved, the setting of the initial values, and the lack of any properties to guarantee the correct working of the filter.

Robinson (1989) proposes a nonparametric estimator to estimate time‐varying coefficients through the maximization of a pseudo‐likelihood based on the assumption that each sequence of coefficients, β i , lies on a smooth function depending on time, \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\{ \beta _{it}=f_{i}( t/ T) \} ^{T}_{t=1}$ \end{document} . The advantage of this estimator is that it does not need a concrete specification of the unknown functionf( ) to determine how coefficients behave in time; that is,f( ) is a smooth, linear, or nonlinear function of the time index. Note that the smoothness assumption is not made over the explained variable, as in the classical nonparametric setting, but over the coefficients. In this sense, as usual in the nonparametric setting, a bandwidth parameter tending to zero permits wiggly coefficients leading to a response variable that connects the observations. But an infinite bandwidth does not imply a horizontal response curve, which is the classical result in nonparametric estimation. In this context, a large amount of smoothness leads to horizontal estimated coefficients, where no variation is allowed, but the estimated response variable can be allowed to float or not depending on the explanatory variables. Although smoothness provides sufficient conditions to both identify and estimate a time‐varying coefficient model, there may exist other qualitative features in the time path that one would like to model through the parameters' behavior. For example, many important economic variables, such as output, consumption, and employment, exhibit seasonal patterns. Unfortunately, seasonal adjusted data contain little or no information about seasonal variation in the parameters and also, as Wallis (1974) and Sims (1974) point out, the use of this type of data in dynamic statistical models can lead to serious misspecification errors. On these grounds, it would be of interest to include seasonal variation in the coefficients' time shape.

Motivated by the preceding reasoning, in this paper, we are interested in the nonparametric estimation of time‐varying coefficients in the presence of seasonality. Among the existing techniques that allow for constraints in nonparametric models (see Mammen, Marron, Turlach, and Wand2001), those that incorporate this information in a constrained optimization fashion appear to be the most appropriate for solving this problem. In our setting, the optimization problem is given by a minimization of a local smoothed sum of squared residuals where the constraints account for the seasonal restrictions in the time‐varying path for the coefficients. The resulting estimator (Orbe, Ferreira, and Rodríguez‐Póo2000and Orbe, Ferreira, and Rodríguez‐Póo2005) is the solution to this constrained optimization problem, and it turns out that it can be included within the class of generalized ridge estimators. Therefore, the method encompasses a great variety of time‐varying parameter models: systematically varying seasonal coefficients models, the Bayesian seasonal smoothness priors estimator of Gersovitz and Mackinnon (1978), the estimator proposed in Robinson (1989), and finally, the time invariant coefficient model. A relation of all these models to the one proposed here can be found in Orbe et al. (2005).

The goal of this paper is to estimate a linear demand equation where it is not reasonable to assume that the parameters are constant over time, because the data used here span a very long period (1907–60), which covers the whole life cycle of the product.1The coefficients of the demand equation may be expected to change during the different stages of the life cycle (see, e.g., Parsons1975), and that is why the nonparametric time varying estimation process is used here. It is quite difficult to compare the performance of this procedure to other methods for the following reasons. First, the procedure is a general descriptive tool, which does not offer any direct possibility of out‐of‐sample prediction as usually used for comparing different procedures. Note that the functions \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\{ f_{i}( t/ T) \} ^{T}_{t=1}$ \end{document} need not be estimated to estimate β it at each momentt. Second, it has no direct competitors: The nearest method might be the Bayesian approach, but its assumptions and model definition (Harrison and West1989; Harvey1989; and Harvey and Scott1994) are completely different. As a result, our procedure can be seen as a prior step to any linear regression for checking whether the coefficient included could be assumed to be constant or whether dummy variables are sufficient to collect the seasonal or nonseasonal shifts. If this is the case, after analyzing the coefficient sequences, the nonparametric estimator provides consistent estimations, but a parametric model can exploit its structure to provide forecasts. Otherwise, when the coefficients follow an unspecified, linear or nonlinear, pattern, we still have consistency. In our nonparametric context, a classical out‐of‐sample forecast cannot be obtained, because our procedure provides an estimated path of coefficients for a sample period but no estimation of the underlying function, which is a necessary tool for making predictions.

The paper is organized as follows.Section IIpresents the evolution from a possible theoretical model to the final specified model and the available data.Section IIIpresents the nonparametric estimation procedure applied in the paper.Section IVdescribes the empirical results obtained, andsection Vconcludes.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: The Koyck Distributed Lag and Data‐Related Issues
sec.p:
The model we estimate is based oneq. (2)and can be written as
where ψ t is an error term that can present heteroscedasticity and autocorrelation. Other potential variables affecting sales have been analyzed in detail in previous studies. Variables such as the volatile mix of media bought with advertising dollars, the total volume of advertising in the country, the number of physicians there, or the per‐capita expenditures on medical care have been found to be irrelevant. Other variables such as personal income, some dummy variables representing discrete (as well as stochastic) changes usually attributed to regulatory activity, and trend variables have also been used in the past. In our study, we need not include any dummy variables or a trend variable in the regression (4) because the parameter β1t collects possible discrete seasonal or trend shifts. Second, a review of past studies suggests that the relevance of personal income is doubtful, and unfortunately, no monthly data are available. Finally, the apparently most‐important price variable is neither included in the regression nor used as a deflator. This is because it is unavailable. It is known only that wholesale price changes occurred very seldom and data on retail prices could not be obtained. Moreover, since the form of the product changed many times (liquid tonic, tablets), no measure of sales in physical units is available; therefore, it is impossible to compute a per‐unit price as sales divided by the number of physical units. Similar difficulties in finding a deflator for advertising led the authors of the existing literature to relate sales to advertising spending in current dollars, and we use the same approach.

Koyck's simple specification of geometrically decaying lagged effects of advertising has been questioned many times for its restrictive hypothesis. See, for example, Bultez and Naert (1979), who compare various lag structures theoretically and empirically, using the same Pinkham data, for a brief review of the literature in which different nonmonotonic lag functions have been proposed. Note that the Koyck structure
turns out, in our specification, to be a very flexible framework, because the three constant coefficients in (5)—α, β0, and θ—are time varying in (4). By the direct comparison of (4) and (2), we note that \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\alpha ( 1-\theta ) $ \end{document} turns out to be β1t , in the same way β0leads to β2t and finally θ to β3t . So that we do not confine ourselves to a unique, rigid lag structure, we choose a very flexible specification that covers a wide range of situations where the lag structure is a smooth function, which is the only assumption we make about our coefficients β1t , β2t and β3t . Moreover, we allow for autocorrelation and heteroscedasticity in our error term ψ t in (4), which can collect dynamics inS
t not included in the right‐hand side explanatory variables. In short, the work is based on a rigid model of geometrically decaying lagged advertising effects, but we make it flexible by allowing for time‐varying parameters.

In practice, when dealing with the sales‐advertising relationships many authors (e.g., Clarke and McCann1973; Bass and Leone1983; and Leach and Reekie1996) coincide in the affirmation that the use of inadequate data intervals leads to a biased estimation of the duration of advertising effect. Clarke (1976, p. 355) analyze the data interval bias that arises when annual data are used and conclude that “the published econometric literature indicates that 90% of the cumulative effect of advertising on sales of mature, frequently purchased, low‐priced products occurs within 3 to 9 months of the advertisement.” Palda's (1964) analysis, for example, implies a 90% duration interval of 59 months using annual data, but monthly data in the same study generate a 4‐month duration interval. Berndt (1991, p. 392) also states that “the ‘true’ 90% duration interval of advertising for most established products is a matter of months and certainly is less than a year …” Therefore, we should not use annual data for estimating parameters in a sales‐advertising relationship of the aforementioned products, or at least we should be very careful in interpreting the results.

Another issue that should be treated in our data is the unit root problem. Baghestani (1991) and Lee et al. (1996) show that the Lydia Pinkham yearly series of sales and advertising areI(1), and as expected, they are cointegrated. Then, if we run a simple OLS regression on these series, we get superconsistent estimators. Moreover, we use monthly data that exhibit very strong seasonal behavior, so that a unit root can easily appear at nonzero frequency, which complicates the cointegration analysis even more.

However, our nonparametric estimator works quite differently. All nonparametric estimators have a bias and a variance term depending on the bandwidth parameter (h) and the number of observations (T). Consistency is obtained only whenhtends to zero andThtends to infinity asTtends to infinity; that is, the number of observations used in a fixed local regression (Th) increases faster than the decrease of the local neighborhood considered. In other words, given a fixed period of time, the number of observations must increase to infinity while the time span between observations decreases. Therefore, nonparametric asymptotic theory requires an increasing frequency in the data collected, so that, when the number of observations (T) goes to infinity, it does not imply that our period increases. It means that, if we start, for example, with yearly data, then the increase inTdoes not imply that the number of years in the sample is larger but that the number of observations increases because of the higher frequency of the data: The sample data become quarterly, monthly, daily, etc. As a result, the cointegration concept makes no sense in our framework: The sample has a fixed length but not a fixed number of observations, therefore, long‐run behaviors cannot be analyzed by our estimation procedure. This issue is treated in more detail in the next section, once the estimator has been derived. Finally, consistency is guaranteed even with nonstationary time series if they are locally stationary as defined in Dahlhaus (1997,2000).

fn.p: But we have to be cautious in interpreting this parameter, as it may collect other effects in this simple model. It may be also a function of other marketing mix elements (distribution channels, personal selling, etc.), product loyalty, or other effects leading to carryover.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Estimation of Time‐Varying Coefficients
sec.p: Few attempts have been made to estimate the advertising‐sales relationship using time‐varying coefficients. Two studies use such data. One is Winer's (1979) study, which is based on Cooley and Prescott's (1973) varying‐parameter regression, where the coefficients change over time according to a random walk. Winer (1979, p. 570) shows that there is substantial evidence of variation of the parameters of the sales‐response model for the Lydia Pinkham yearly data. Beckwith (1972) analyzes Lydia Pinkham annual data assuming different patterns of change in the coefficients of advertising. Assuming constant parameters for various advertising copy eras obtained reduced effectiveness due to regulatory activity in 1914 and a major increase in 1941 due to copy changes.

The nonparametric estimation procedure used in our study permits the estimation of a time‐varying coefficient model, where the coefficients are allowed to have a nonspecific smooth and seasonal pattern. The proposed estimator nests many other estimators proposed in literature as particular cases and allows any combination of the particular cases described previously. Unfortunately, since the estimator is based on the kernel estimation, it suffers from boundary problems. In our procedure, these boundary effects depend on the structure of the coefficients. That is, if the coefficients are constant or step functions, there are no boundary effects, since the estimation procedure detects deterministic behavior. But, when the coefficients follow more complex functions, boundary effects appear. The simulation study in Orbe et al. (2005) shows that boundary effects in the cases where coefficients follow a decreasing, quadratic, and sinusoidal function are rather small. Nevertheless, these effects can be overcome by traditional techniques used in nonparametric estimation. Given that, in our empirical applications, the parameter estimates are smooth functions, similar to a sinusoidal function, we do not apply these techniques.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Empirical Results
sec.p: Model (4) is estimated using data from the original study by Palda (1964). The data are monthly observations over two periods. The first period goes from 1908:01 to 1926:12 and the second from 1938:01 to 1959:12. Observations 1907:12 and 1937:12 are used for the first lag valuesS 0. Data between these two samples are not available on a monthly basis. The subsamples are estimated separately to make the model more flexible, as the amount of imposed smoothness and seasonality need not be the same.

A typical problem when treating advertising and sales data is their possible simultaneity. This problem probably will not emerge here, because the feedback effect of sales on advertising is expected to occur over periods longer than the data frequency (monthly).

The estimation of the time‐varying coefficients requires a decision about the choice of the kernel function and the amount of their smoothness and seasonality. That means that the values ofh, λ1, λ2, and λ3have to be chosen for both periods under study.

The product under study was a herbal extract in an alcoholic solution, which is why it went through many controversies. In 1907–14, the product was advertised as a universal remedy. In 1914, the product was threatened with taxation as an alcoholic beverage because of its 18% alcohol content, and the firm was accused of false and misleading advertising. That is why the advertising claim changed in 1915–25 to relief for menstrual problems. In 1925, Pinkham was required to advertise its compound only as a vegetable tonic and approximately at the same time, in 1926, the recently promoted new director, who was the granddaughter of the founder, came to dominate company advertising decisions and refused to cut advertising when sales fell. So advertising changed in 1926–40 to vegetable tonic to turn finally once more to relief for menstrual problems in 1941–60.3Obviously, all these changes, together with different stages of the life cycle of the product, must have had some impact on sales and on the response of sales to advertising over the long data period under study.

The data include three of the four major subperiods of the firm's history mentioned previously: subperiod 1 (1907–14, universal remedy era), subperiod 2 (1915–25, relief for menstrual problems era), and subperiod 4 (1941–60, relief for menstrual problems era).4

The third subperiod, maturity, coincides with the gap in the data, so that we are unable to observe the evolution of the coefficients in the period, where a firm usually seeks to gain and maintain its market position by pricing actions such as deals.

Given the pointwise confidence intervals and almost constant evolution of the estimations of β2t and β3t , we can say that these two coefficients can be assumed to be constant in the years 1907–14 and 1949–60.

Figure 6presents the length of the 90% duration interval based on IV estimation and computed according toeq. (3). This interval shifts between 2.5 and 5 months in the first subsample and stays nearly stable at close to 4 months in the final years of the product life cycle, confirming that the 90% duration interval is a question of months, not years (Clarke1976, p. 355). Finally, the adjusted sales (figures 4and5) show that our estimation procedure performs almost perfectly for both the seasonal and nonseasonal shifts observed in both subsamples. Fig. 6.—

The difference between the two point estimations is reasonable, because the varying parameter regression method is based on the idea of decomposition of the changes in the parameters into permanent and transient parts (similar to a Kalman filter). The resulting estimator is the generalized least squares method with a time‐varying disturbance variance‐covariance matrix. The performance of this procedure is conditioned on its initial values and simplifying assumption as the equality of covariance matrices of permanent and transient parts.

Another reason for the difference in the estimations presented intable 1is the number of observations used in each approach, like the yearly data used by Winer (1979), offer only 54 observations. We applied Cooley and Prescott's (1973) varying parameter regression to monthly data to obtain a more‐comparable outcome, but we obtained unexpected results similar to those described by Winer (1979, p. 572). We found no initial values for the covariances of the permanent and transitory changes of the coefficients that would lead to expected values.

In all figures, we should be cautious in interpreting those nonparametric estimations close to the start or the end of each subsample, because in addition to the existing bias derived from the use of a nonparametric estimator (see Orbe et al.2005for specific bias of our estimator), there exists a boundary effect as stated at the end of section III. This is because the bandwidth used for the estimation of each of these points selects periods that are out of sample. As a result, some observations on the left‐hand side of the bandwidth are not available when we deal with observations in the starting periods of the sample (nor are some observations on the right‐hand side when we deal with the last observations of the sample). In these cases, the number of usable observations is lower than that indicated by the selection method. This is why these estimations are not as reliable as other points further from the starting and ending points.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: As stated in the Introduction section, the estimation procedure applied in this paper is a descriptive tool that should be used to find out whether coefficients of a proposed parametric model can be assumed to be constant, which is a crucial assumption for avoiding inconsistency and misleading results.

We use the famous data set of the Lydia Pinkham Medicine Company to find out something new in this complicated sales‐advertising relationship. Our results, obtained from monthly data, basically support Winer's (1979) conclusions, obtained by a different procedure and from yearly data. Our method, using almost 500 observations, however, offers more‐precise estimations and, to the best of our knowledge, is the first nonparametric procedure applied to these famous monthly data.

An important point of our procedure is the possibility of estimating a stochastic seasonal behavior. Our point estimations of the carryover effect and advertising coefficient present seasonal movements, but the confidence limits are wide enough to make this seasonality insignificant.

In summary, our estimations indicate that the parameters of the sales response model change over time, which is an expected conclusion, as the data sample spans a very long period. The carryover effect and advertising coefficient can be considered constant only in some subperiods.

This is an important conclusion, because decision rules to determine the optimal advertising budget can be based on the estimation of a demand equation similar toeq. (2). If such rules are based on a wrong constant parameter assumption, then a nonconsistent estimation can invalidate any decision rule.

Bultez and Naert (1979), for example, compare various lag structures for the sales response to changes in advertising and derive the corresponding decision rules for determining the optimal advertising budget. Their empirical study is based on the last 78 monthly observations of the sample used in this paper. This was a fortunate selection, as their study is based on a constant‐elasticity demand relationship and, as shown in the previous section, the advertising coefficient can be considered constant for this period. If they had chosen a period in which this coefficient varied over time (for example, 1916–30), their conclusions would have been based on an inconsistent estimation of the sales‐goodwill elasticity and the corresponding decision rule would have been misleading.

The new empirical industrial organization models, incorporating basically demand and first‐order optimization conditions of firms, together with the econometric estimation of these relations, have to be developed and generalized in various directions. One such direction is surely the modeling of richer dynamic structures (Sudhir, Chintagunta, and Kadiyali2002; Pakes and Ericson1998; Chung and Kaiser2000). In this sense, the application of our procedure to a demand equation provides many important insights into dynamic behavior of firms. However. “modelling dynamics in a fully structural context turns out to be a challenging task” (Kadiyali, Sudhir, and Rao2001, p. 176).
